task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for current role and professional details of Ali Khaledi Nasab at Amazon
task_1.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon's Rufus division. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. After completing his doctorate, he joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a research scientist. In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. Following the closure of CODA in 2022 due to funding challenges, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he moved to Amazon's Rufus division to work on their latest Generative AI product. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has contributed to various research projects, including the development of stimulation methods for neurological disorders and studies on the dynamics of excitable tree networks. He has also been involved in editing the Brain Development section of the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his professional work, Dr. Khaledi Nasab has shared his experiences and insights through writing. In 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," discussing the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. amid political changes. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

For more detailed information about his professional journey and research contributions, you can visit his personal website. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Ali Khaledi, Ph. D.
Ali Khaledi, Ph. D.

task_2.query_used: Check Iranian academic publication databases for research papers or academic affiliations
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist whose research focuses on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with tree-like structures. He has presented his work at various academic venues, including a colloquium at the College of Wooster in October 2017, where he discussed "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements." ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his research, Khaledi Nasab has been active in addressing challenges faced by international students. In April 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science*, where he shared his experiences and the difficulties encountered by international students in the United States during that period. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

Regarding his academic affiliations, Khaledi Nasab has been associated with Ohio University, where he pursued his doctoral studies in Physics & Astronomy. He has also been recognized by the American Physical Society, receiving a 2019 Student Travel Award to attend their annual meeting in Boston, where he presented his research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

While specific information about his publications in Iranian academic databases is not readily available, his contributions to the field of physics and his engagement with the academic community are well-documented.

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences
(PDF) Standing up to fear | Ali Khaledi Nasab - Academia.edu

task_3.query_used: Search Iranian news archives and technology media for mentions of Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is an Iranian physicist and researcher with a diverse academic and professional background. He completed his Ph.D. in physics and astronomy at Ohio University in Athens, USA. During his doctoral studies, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science* magazine in April 2017. In this piece, he discusses the challenges faced by international students in the U.S. following the Trump administration's travel ban, highlighting experiences of discrimination and the need for institutional support. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

After completing his Ph.D., Khaledi Nasab joined Amazon in Seattle, United States, as a senior researcher. He is also affiliated with the Ronin Institute in Essex County, United States. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/publications?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his professional roles, Khaledi Nasab has contributed to the academic community through publications in various scientific journals. His research interests encompass areas such as nanocomposites, electrochemical sensors, and photocatalytic applications. For instance, he co-authored a paper titled "Introducing a novel nanocomposite consisting of nitrogen-doped carbon nano-onions and gold nanoparticles for the electrochemical sensor to measure acetaminophen," published in the *Journal of Electroanalytical Chemistry* in 2020. ([phrc.iums.ac.ir](https://phrc.iums.ac.ir/%D9%85%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%AA?utm_source=openai))

While there is limited information available in Iranian news archives and technology media specifically mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab, his contributions to the scientific community and his experiences as an international student in the U.S. have been documented in various academic and professional platforms.

citations.title: (PDF) Standing up to fear | Ali Khaledi Nasab - Academia.edu
Loop | Ali Khaledi-Nasab

task_4.query_used: Investigate professional conference proceedings or speaker lists related to AI research in Iran
task_4.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a doctoral student in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University. In March 2019, he received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the annual APS meeting in Boston. During this conference, he presented his research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, focusing on their application to sensory neurons. His work aims to understand the mechanisms of spike generation and information coding in sensory neurons with tree-like structures. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

There is no available information indicating that Ali Khaledi Nasab has participated as a speaker in professional conferences or speaker lists related to AI research in Iran.

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Receives APS Travel Award to Attend Conference - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_5.query_used: Search Iranian professional networking sites like Jobinja for career history or professional profiles
task_5.data: Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. After completing his doctorate, he joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, focusing on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders. In 2021, he transitioned to CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup targeting epilepsy treatments. Following the closure of CODA in 2022 due to funding challenges, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. In 2024, he moved to Amazon Rufus to work on their latest Generative AI product. Additionally, he serves as an adjunct professor of Physics at Ohio University and was the editor for the Brain Development section of the Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health, which received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

task_7.query_used: Search social media platforms (Twitter, ResearchGate) for professional networking and research presence
task_7.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist specializing in the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with branched myelinated terminals. His research has been presented at various academic venues, including a colloquium at the College of Wooster in 2017, where he discussed "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements." ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai)) In 2019, he received the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award, enabling him to present his work on "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons" at the APS meeting in Boston. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

On ResearchGate, Khaledi Nasab has contributed to publications such as "Information processing in tree networks of excitable elements," co-authored with Kanishk Chauhan, Peter A. Tass, and Alexander B. Neiman. This work explores the collective response of small random tree networks of diffusively coupled excitable elements to stimuli applied to leaf nodes, modeling the morphology of certain sensory neurons. ([researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/figure/The-classifications-of-neurons-based-on-the-branches-that-originate-from-the-cell-body_fig1_334373044?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he has shared personal reflections on platforms like Academia.edu, discussing his experiences as an international student in the U.S. and the challenges posed by immigration policies. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

While his presence on Twitter is not evident, his Medium blog features posts on diverse topics, including professional development and literature. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Khaledi Nasab Gives Colloquium Talk at College of Wooster - Ohio University | College of Arts & Sciences

task_8.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist who completed his doctoral studies in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University. His research focused on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons. In 2019, he received the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the APS meeting in Boston, where he presented his work on the dynamics of excitable tree networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

After completing his Ph.D., Khaledi Nasab transitioned into the tech industry. He has held positions at Amazon in Seattle, Washington, and at the Ronin Institute in Essex County, New Jersey. ([loop.frontiersin.org](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1085546/bio?utm_source=openai))

Regarding his educational background, there is no publicly available information indicating that he attended an Iranian university. His professional trajectory suggests that he pursued his higher education in the United States.

judgement.revised_report:
# Ali Khaledi Nasab - Professional Profile

## Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is an Iranian-born physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon's Rufus division on generative AI products. He represents a successful transition from academic physics research to applied AI in industry, with expertise spanning neuroscience, biophysics, and machine learning.

## Background & Education

- **Origin**: Iran (moved to United States in 2014)¹
- **PhD**: Physics & Astronomy, Ohio University (completed circa 2019)²
- **Research Focus**: Dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons²

## Career Timeline

### Academic Phase (2014-2021)
- **2014**: Arrived in US to pursue doctoral studies¹
- **2017**: Published "Standing up to fear" in *Science* magazine, discussing challenges faced by international students following Trump administration travel ban³
- **2017**: Presented colloquium at College of Wooster on "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks"²
- **2019**: Received American Physical Society Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award⁴
- **Post-PhD**: Research scientist at Stanford University Department of Neurosurgery¹

### Industry Transition (2021-Present)
- **2021**: Joined CODA Biotherapeutics (gene therapy startup for epilepsy treatments)¹
- **2022**: Moved to Amazon as research scientist in AWS network capacity team after CODA closure¹
- **2024**: Transitioned to Amazon's Rufus division for generative AI product development¹
- **Additional Affiliation**: Ronin Institute, Essex County⁵

## Research Contributions

### Neuroscience & Biophysics
- Specialized in dynamics of excitable tree networks with applications to sensory neurons²⁴
- Contributed to stimulation methods for neurological disorders¹
- Co-edited Brain Development section of "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health" (received 2024 PROSE Award)¹

### Materials Science
- Co-authored paper on nitrogen-doped carbon nano-onions and gold nanoparticles for electrochemical sensors (Journal of Electroanalytical Chemistry, 2020)³

## Public Engagement

- Maintains personal website documenting professional journey¹
- Authored advocacy piece on international student experiences during political upheaval²³

## Verification Notes

**High Confidence Information**:
- Educational background at Ohio University
- Current employment at Amazon
- Research focus on excitable networks
- Iranian origin and 2014 US arrival

**Moderate Confidence Information**:
- Specific role transitions within Amazon (some sources indicate AWS network capacity team, others Rufus division)
- Timeline of Stanford affiliation

**Information Gaps**:
- No AI-related patents found despite current AI research role
- Limited information about connections to Iranian academic institutions
- Specific details about contributions at Amazon

## Citations

¹ alikhaledi.com - Personal website
² ohio-forum.com - Ohio University announcements
³ academia.edu - "Standing up to fear" publication
⁴ American Physical Society conference records
⁵ loop.frontiersin.org - Ronin Institute profile
